title: Assesment of surface ravelling using traffic speed survey techniques
segmentation: Right, I'm going to be talking about the assessment of surface raveling using traffic speed survey techniques.
In the UK.
We sort of have a mix between the terminology of raveling and fretting and I'll try and explain what we mean by the difference between those two those two measures.
This work has been carried out for the UK Highways Agency in partnership with McDonald's.
To assess the, set the measurement of fretting on the UK Rd network and I've got a presentation split into roughly 4 parts.
I'm first of all going to talk about our problem with fretting on the Highways Agency network.
What we do at the moment.
And these defects at traffic speed.
And then I'm going to discuss the development of some algorithms that we've been producing at TRL, to try and determine and identify the presence of fretting.
OK, but what is fretting, fretting, raveling?
Two similar things, but slightly different.
In the UK we we've got a trunk Rd network which is split into broadly two distinct surface types with a bit of concrete tagged on the end.
But I'm not going to talk about that.
The border there means main service type we've had.
Historically it's been hot rolled asphalt which deteriorates in.
Heavily with the loss of Stone in the surface, and we often call that loss of stone.
This is this is appears as a stone being lost from the bit him in the binder.
Well we sometimes call it plucking and you get this appearance of loss of stone, but the binder remains.
On the mall.

In more recent servicing that we've been laying in, the UK are thin surface is the payment deteriorates in a slightly different way in that the stones themselves get lost from the matrix and you get a collapse and you can have a rapid deterioration of the payment.

We actually have fretted HRA surfaces that have been looked that way for the last 20 years and still seem to be going strong, but the thin surface things tend to collapse quite quickly once this deterioration appears.
Right, well, why does it matter to us?
Well, I actually just trying to pick up some tips from Chris.
Is talk about measuring the right things at the right time and the right frequency and it the way.

It matters to us really is is that we run a process of continuous value management in in in in England, on the trunk Rd network where we try and determine the optimum point to intervene and carry out maintenance.
This is done by taking data from our automatic surveys and assessing the data to identify sites that are in need of attention.
Now we currently don't have good information on that for the presence of surface deterioration such as fretting.
And that makes it more difficult for us to determine when we should be carrying out the ultimate intervention on those sites.
And we would like to be able to determine and predict how these sites are going to deteriorate and how this defect will deteriorate overtime.
So we really have an objective to deliver a good measure of fretting that we can deliver to the Highways Agency maintaining agents who each are responsible for maintaining each part of our network.
At the moment, surveys of fretting are carried out using what we call coarse visual inspections.
These inspections are carried out from the windscreen of a moving vehicle.

We don't carry out any routine manual surveys on the trunk Rd network in the UK at all, so there are no closures carried out for can visual condition surveys until agents of identified sites for maintenance purposes.
So we we.

We attempt to identify all defects using moving surveys because we don't have a good system of identifying fretting, we still use the course visual inspection, which does include measurement of other defects as well, but it records fretting by the the inspector visually just writing down when he sees the presence of fretting.
It's not characterized in terms of the extent of the defect, and we're finding this quite difficult to quantify.
Definitely impossible to trend and.
Pretty difficult to repeat, so from month to month, year to year, these surveys you you can't really say what's happening.
What are other key measurement of condition on the trunk roads?
Is the traffic condition, surveys or tracks now this surveys carried out frequently using high speed multifunction survey vehicle.

Which measures transverse profile longitudinal profile text your profile in one measurement line and cracking cracking is measured using visual image collection followed by 4th fully automatic or fully automatic analysis crack detection to report the presence of cracking back to the user of the data.
Transverse profile is converted in writing language and profile is converted into ride quality and texture profile is used at the moment primarily to give you an assessment of the.

To assist in high speed skid resistance estimates, to tell you about the watershed incapabilities of the surface of the payment, we carry out these surveys on A6 monthly basis on Lane one of the network and Lane two.
We carry out survey every year with slip roads being done over a two year basis of two year survey giving us 45,000 kilometers a year.
Using the track survey.
I'm actually going to be talking later in the week about our scanner survey of local roads in the UK, which covers an additional 100,000 kilometers a year.
OK.
So.
Track survey.
Currently delivers a measurement of texture profile in the near side wheel path.
It does say nearside and offside here that that's just wrong.
I'm afraid.
The measurements provided standard traditional 3264 kilohertz lasers.
Both of these measurements meet our requirement technical requirements and we use this as I said to look at the shape of shipping the watershed incapability.
But we have considered the use of this for measuring fretting and we've used to measure of the beat was proposed by the Divey called the Stone Way method.
Think how does a clever combination of two words being stone and away and some wit give you stoneway.

This measure was developed for forest asphalt and takes the one laser measurement line in the near side wheel path to report the loss of these stones being lost from the payment that we took this measure and tuned it for measuring fretting on hot rolled asphalt.
And.
I've applied it actually for the last couple of two or three years in England to measure fretting.
However, we've had a few problems with it.

It was cheering for measuring hot rolled Asheville and there it was only successful where fretting appeared in the wheel path and we don't actually get fretting, only appear in the wealthy, specially on HRA where it does tend to appear right across the width of the pavement.

It didn't work on other surface types because of the tuning requirement and we needed to workout whether we could improve that to extend it to other late to extend it to cover the full width of the payment so that we don't have to.
So we don't miss defects.
Whether we could consider it for more than one surface type, because about half of our network is now thin surfacing.
And.
Whether that would be a satisfactory measure?
Now, to do this we've we look.
We wanted to have a system where the.
The measurements could be collected without having to upgrade our systems heavily, and that means not having to provide by expensive GNU measurement systems.
And so that we could continue with our national survey.

And we looked back at the technology that we're getting out of standard survey equipment and our Harris one vehicle, which is our prototype device that we use for quality assurance in the UK and the transverse profile measurement system.

No transverse profile measurements provided by these devices, and there are dozens of these in the around the world are typically provided over survey frequency of about 100 millimeters down the road.
To give you a transverse profile from which you measure writing.
But the lasers that are providing that data actually can measure much more frequently.

They measure traffic speed and then measuring multiple lines, so each laser effectively can be used to give you a texture profile across the full Lane and Lane width, and that's what we've done with our transformation system in the UK.
We've taken the transverse profiles over 25 points and we asked Greenwood Engineering who are a supplier of.
Our equipment to upgrade it to deliver us the raw data and this was actually quite cheap, didn't require any hardware upgrade system at all.
And amazingly for Greenwood they actually provided it quite quickly.
That's the end plug for Greenwood Engineering.
The laser standard 16 kilohertz lasers and we're getting a transverse profile now every 6 millimeters in which we refer to as pseudo texture.
The first thing that.
We've done is taking our stoneway algorithm, the divey, and applied it to the multiple line texture too.
To measure fretting on hot rolled asphalt in multiple lines, the stoneway measurement just takes 25.
The 25 lines filters the data divided into segments and establish is a baseline and looks for holes.
To get the holes you have to get put in some device.
Device customizable parameters, and this is actually a very simple process which is looking for where stones are missing, which is where there is a hole of a suitable length.
And we tuned our pseudo texture profile to identify these holes.
To do this, we actually needed initially to carry some reference data and this surveys were carried out for us by McDonald's, where we?
Asked a surveyor to walk down the hard shoulder and assess the extent of fretting across the width of the traffic Lane using a simple grid basis.
They split the road in 2.7 meter wide strips so you get about five across the road and every 5 meters.
They reported how much fretting was within that strip.
And they gave it a rating for Norton 3 not being no fretting, 3 being heavy fretting shown by red.
We also attempted to take measurements with our.

Image for image collection system which does give us downward facing videos of the surface, the pavement and we were able to classify some of the sites is being fretted is actually not always easy on a hot rolled asphalt pavement.
Actually very easy to take fretting images, but on a thin surfacing these can be pretty difficult to spot.

So using an iterative process, we compared the reference data obtained using these manual survey techniques with the results of our algorithm and produced tuned it down to get values of DNL to identify length of fretting and I think if I.
You've got sort of a progressive adjustment of the parameters to try and define what the right value of DNLR.
Looked at it over long length so this is the results of the algorithm comparing the.
Multiple linedata border fretting against the manual assessment on site identifying red spots in the same place and no fretting in the same place.

And then compare the two and we've actually reasonably happy with the results over algorithm and when we felt that you could probably take that out onto the network and use it to assess fretting at the network level, subject to having that raw data from your survey vehicle, which is a side again an easy upgrade for the survey vehicles that we already have on the network.
However, one of the problems we have with this is it still only works on Hot Rolled Asheville.
And we would therefore need to be able to develop it and tune it to look at threat.
Being on hold on overhaul of our network and we weren't really happy with that and we looked at the options that we have now.
Some ways to do this is to develop an automatic surface type measure so you can just junior algorithm identifier surface type.
Say we use these parameters on that surface type.
We rely on the engineers to tell us what surface type they've laid and after after everyone had got up finishing laughing, we decided that wasn't a good idea.
Or we develop a new measure which is independent of surface type but can still tell us about the fretting and that's something I'm just going to cover briefly now.
Which is the development of a different approach for measuring surface aeration using this multiple line data?
Right?

What we're looking for is a measurement to tell you when the surface is deteriorated, and with our approach that we're taking to this is to no longer look for these specific loss of stones that we're doing with the development of of the divey method, but to just look at the detection of raw.

General surface deterioration by assessing with the texture over the full width of the pavement and look, we've done that by looking at what does the text look like over long lengths and what's the texture look like over short lengths, and the best way to share this is probably just with some video video visual examples.
I'll come back to that.
Actually.
This is a surface where there is no fretting apparent.
You can't see much over the width of the road and we look at the texture grid that we're developing with our multiple line system.
And this shows you that if you look at the.
Whole of the right over 100 meter length you just get a broad array of texture.
This is this is RMS texture values generated from this multiple line data.
6 millimeter data expressed in a grid and you just get a pretty much of a general.
Situation.
And if you focus in on any local length, the distribution is just replicated only locally and you can see that by looking at distributions of texture.
Over these 10 and 100 meter lengths.
So this is our individual 10 meter lengths and this is just the distribution over the whole road 100 meters.
But then look at some fretted payments.
And here you can see quite clearly in video images of the pavement how the fretting appears.
You can see the loss of stone, but without texture system we can characterize this.
And here you can see that the.
The text you later again, this is from the transverse preformation system.
Not upgraded is giving you highlighting the places where this losses this stone is being lost and the distributions of the texture very different.
It's a much broader distribution, and if you subtract any of the distributions from the local one, you get a rather trait different strange shape.

Shown here, so distributions on a fretted payment, broad distributions and unfretted pavement narrow and quite a big change when you try and characterize the differences between the global global texture and the local texture over the fretted length.
So.

We've been going ahead trying to develop characteristics to identify local surface deterioration by comparing texture changes locally with those done over long lengths and at the moment we are still on early days of this development, but we've come up with a few parameters and the parameters are looking at correlation which is correlating the shape of the local distribution with that of the global distribution.
As I said, very different looking at the width of the distribution of called someone called the texture ratio and also looking at something called the local difference.
Which is assessing the texture along each measurement line and checking whether there is variability in that line.
'cause one of the problems with this method is is that if local text if the if you have array which is covered in fretting, it just looks awful all the time, so you can't.
You can't compare long and short lengths.
That helps you with doing that.
And we combine these to produce a final parameter to assess the.
Sort of wearing the texture along with.
It's the road.
And we're getting reasonably satisfaction.
Satisfaction results this over 100 kilometer length that we've tested.
And we're going to be taking this forward onto wider parts the network.
See if we can get data ID carry out more testing.
Suggest to summarize there.
In the UK we have a problem with setting on the network, which we'd like to characterize.
We'd like to quantify, and we'd like to trend it.

We feel that you can replace the current slow speed measurements of fretting carried out from windscreen surveys and on site with traffic speak techniques specially being as the multifunction devices get more and more have more potential.
We've taken a device which is the standard machine delivering transverse profile.
Upgraded the software to deliver the raw measurements.
And then looks at those raw measurements to try and characterize text fretting.
We've taken him a system from Divey and use that on hot rolled asphalt and had some success.
But we feel that we're going to have difficulties generalizing that over our entire network.

Say what we're doing is we've moved our approach to look at the change in texture of the variability in texture over the road surface and comparing local and global texture to see whether it will highlight deterioration.
That work is ongoing and we're going to be carrying out wider testing and introducing texture measurements from image collection as well to combine it with the laser based systems.
I think they finished.
